Arden Edwards<br>Grace Oliver | architecture = | added = February 26, 1987 | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | refnum = 87000509 | mpsub = | governing_body = }} }} The '''Antelope Valley Indian Museum State Historic Park''' is a [[California State Historic Park|state historic park]] of [[California]], USA, interpreting [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] cultures of the [[Great Basin]] and surrounding regions. The park and its grounds are situated on the [[Antelope Valley]]'s rural east side in northern [[Los Angeles County, California]]. The museum contains the combined collections of H. Arden Edwards and subsequent owner and anthropology student Grace Oliver. The exhibits represent and interpret Native Americans groups, both aboriginal and contemporary, of the [[Southwest United States|Southwest]], Great Basin, and [[Californian Indian|Californian]] cultural regions. A number of the artifacts on display are rare or one-of-a-kind items. The museum was originally constructed by homesteader/artist H. Arden Edwards in 1928. The chalet-style structure was built over the rock formation of Piute Butte in the [[Mojave Desert]]. The unusual [[folk art]] structure, originally used as a home, is listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]]. ==Demonstrations and special events== Joshua Cottage features a "touch table" room where visitors can experience food grinding and processing techniques, or learn how earlier Native Americans started fires using sticks or bow drills. Outside the museum is a self-guided [[nature trail]], a [[picnic]] area, and an outdoor ceremonial arena. Occasionally guest Native American groups perform traditional dances and other programs. An annual opening event each fall features a traditional ground blessing ceremony. There are also Native American artists demonstrating and selling their work, Native American food, and special activities for children. The museum also sponsors periodic educational seminars. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.avim.parks.ca.gov/ Official '''Antelope Valley Indian Museum State Historic Park''' website] *[http://www.parks.ca.gov/default.asp?page_id=632 California State Parks: Antelope Valley Indian Museum website] * Antelope Valley Indian Museum Curator Peggy Ronning [http://esotouric.com/canteatsunshine21 interviewed] for the You Can't Eat The Sunshine podcast (2013). {{Protected Areas of California|SP}} {{Registered Historic Places}} [[Category:California State Historic Parks]] [[Category:Antelope Valley]] [[Category:Museums in Los Angeles County, California]] [[Category:Native American museums in California]] [[Category:Geography of Palmdale, California]] [[Category:History of Los Angeles County, California]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places listings in Los Angeles County, California]] [[Category:Parks in Los Angeles County, California]] [[Category:Protected areas of the Mojave Desert]] [[Category:Protected areas established in 1979]] [[Category:1979 establishments in California]]
